metadata.title: Single non-noble-metal cobalt atom stabilized by pyridinic vacancy graphene: An efficient catalyst for CO oxidation
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Table 1 Models Reaction steps Barriers Models Reaction steps Barriers Cu-Gra21 CO+O→CO2 0.54 Fe-Gra22 CO+O2 →CO3 0.58 Pt-Gra76 CO+O→CO2 0.46 Al-Gra80 CO+O2 →OOCO 0.32 Pt-O/Gra13 CO+O2 →O+CO2 0.76 Pt-Ge/Gra77 CO+O2 →O+CO2 0.86 Au-NB74 OCO−OCO→2CO2 0.47 Fe-NB79 CO+O→CO2 0.61 Single non-noble-metal cobalt atom stabilized by pyridinic vacancy graphene: An efficient catalyst for CO oxidation Xilin Zhang a Zhansheng Lu a b Zongxian Yang a b ⁎ a College of Physics and Materials Science, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang 453007, China College of Physics and Materials Science Henan Normal University Xinxiang 453007 China b Collaborative Innovation Center of Nano Functional Materials and Applications, Henan Province, China Collaborative Innovation Center of Nano Functional Materials and Applications Henan Province China ⁎ Corresponding author at: College of Physics and Materials Science, Henan Normal University, Xinxiang 453007, China. College of Physics and Materials Science Henan Normal University Xinxiang 453007 China Graphical abstract CO oxidation catalyzed by the non-noble metal Cobalt coupled with pyridinic N3 graphene along the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. The low operating temperature, high efficiency and noble-metal-free are the goal of the ideal catalysts. In present study, an efficient noble-metal-free catalyst for CO oxidation with a single cobalt atom incorporated with pyridinic nitrogen graphene (Co-N3-gra) is proposed. The catalytic activity for CO oxidation via various mechanisms on the Co-N3-gra catalyst is investigated using the first-principles method. It is found that the CO oxidation occurs preferably following the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism (CO+O2 →OOCO→CO2 +O) with an energy barrier of 0.86eV for the rate-limiting step of OOCO formation. Our findings prove that the activity of noble-metal-free Co-N3-gra catalyst is comparable to or even higher than some other single noble-metal-graphene based catalysts. Keywords Single Co atom Noble-metal-free CO oxidation Pyridinic N Density functional theory 1 Introduction Rationally design of the high efficient and cheaper catalysts with low operating temperature to replace the conventional noble metal catalysts that are always costly and need high operating temperatures for CO oxidation [1–6] has attracted considerable attention in order to solve the environmental problems caused by CO emission. Given the high price and limitedness of noble metals, downsizing the size of nanoparticles while keeping the catalytic activity is of great significance. The catalytic performance of nanoparticles depends more on their morphology than on size [7] since the activity of nanoparticles is determined by the d states of transition metal that are influenced strongly by the local coordination environments and unsaturated atoms [8,9]. In this sense, designing the single transition metal atom catalyst, no matter isolated [10,11] or supported [12,13], may meet the goal of low cost and high density of activated sites for catalytic reactions. Compared with the isolated single atom catalyst, the supported catalyst is easier to realize in practice and always with higher activity since the interaction of single atom with substrate could tune the charge redistribution that usually affects the catalytic performance of the composite catalyst [13]. Actually, the supported single atom catalysts that combining the highly activated single transition metal atoms and suitable support materials have been experimentally prepared and testified with a fascinating reactivity for CO oxidation [14–17]. The exceptional catalytic activity arising from the high reactivity of the partially occupied d states that were shifted to the Fermi level due to the interaction of transition metal atoms with substrate [18]. Significantly, the graphene, especially the modified graphene coupled with the metal atoms has motivated tremendous interest since the compound catalysts always exhibit excellent stability and amazing activity for many reactions including CO oxidation [19–22] and oxygen reduction [23–25]. Introducing vacancy or foreign dopants are two commonly accepted methods to create activated sites for stabilizing the supported metal atoms while keeping the large surface-to-volume ratio of graphene. The non-metal dopant such as Si, P and N could significantly improve the reactivity of graphene by tuning the electronic structures and local curvature [26–28]. Especially, the N doped graphene systems with different doping configurations have been studied extensively and are recognized as a promising alternative catalyst for oxygen reduction [29,30] and nitride oxide removal [31,32]. Further, the single metal atoms such as Pt and Co embedded in defective graphene or adsorbed on the doped graphene have become hot research topics both theoretically [18,33,34] and experimentally [35–37]. For example, the recent experimental study pointed out that the N doped graphene as substrate could efficiently stabilize the Pt nanoparticles, and the resulting supported catalysts exhibited high performance for methanol oxidation [37]. Some theoretical works also proved that the stability and activity of single atom Pt supported on graphene can be improved by nitrogen dopant [19,34,38]. Interestingly, some researches have shown that the activity of metal-nitrogen codoped graphene catalysts depends primarily on the selected metal atom, N-containing precursor, carbon support and heat treatment [39–41]. The modified graphene combination of the base metals such as Co and nitrogen has also been suggested as an alternative catalyst to reduce the cost without lowering the catalytic activity [42–45]. Therefore, the metal Co coupled with nitrogen doped graphene with various arrangement modes were constructed and the catalytic performance for ORR was accordingly evaluated [42,46–51]. It is pointed out that the metal Co incorporated with nitrogen plays an important role in promoting ORR activity by improving the content of Co-N active sites [43,49,52], and the central metal Co could activate the bonded nitrogen and/or carbon atoms [46,48,52]. Although the high activity of N and Co codoped graphene is unanimous, the real doping configuration is controversial [46,48,53]. Likewise, although there are so many experimental and theoretical researches focusing almost completely on the ORR activity of the N-Co codoped graphene with various arrangement patterns, the catalytic activity of N-Co codoped graphene towards CO oxidation which is also an important industrial reaction seems to be scarce to date. The geometric structures and electronic properties of CO oxidation involved species adsorbed on the N-Co codoped graphene are indistinct, and the mechanism of CO oxidation on the N-Co codoped graphene is also unclarified. To this end, the first-principles calculations are performed to systematically investigate the reaction process of CO oxidation on the N-Co codoped graphene. Our results indicate that the single Co atom embedded into the pyridinic vacancy site of nitrogen doped graphene is more stable than that of Pt [38]. CO oxidation on the Co-N codoped graphene would readily proceed through the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism with a rate-limiting step barrier of 0.86eV for peroxide-like intermediate formation. 2 Computational method The spin-unrestricted density functional theory (DFT) calculations are performed by the DMol3 code [54,55] embedded in Materials Studio. A double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set is used, while the ion–electron interaction is described by DFT semicore pseudopotentials [56] (DSPPs). The empirical dispersion-corrected density functional theory (DFT-D) [57,58] is used to describe the Van der Waals interaction between the reactants or intermediates with the substrate. The exchange and correlation functional of Perdew, Burke and Ernzerhof (PBE) within the generalized gradient approximation [59] (GGA) is used for structure relaxations and energy minimization. The convergence criteria are set to 10−5 Ha for the energy, 0.002Ha/Å for the force, and 0.005Å for the displacement. The smearing value is set to 0.005Ha to achieve self-consistent field convergence. A modified hexagonal graphene with a 4×4 supercell is adopted, and the vacuum layer is set to 15Å to avoid the interactions among mirror images. The linear synchronous transition/quadratic synchronous transit (LST/QST) tools [60] are used to locate the minimum energy pathway (MEP), which have been well validated to locate the transition state (TS) structure and the MEP. The reaction barriers and the corresponding reaction heats are all estimated with respect to their direct precursor. The reciprocal space is sampled with 5×5×1 k-points grid generated automatically using the Monkhorst–Pack method [61] for the relaxation calculations and TSs search, while a 21×21×1 k-points grid is used for the electronic properties calculations. Moreover, transition states are identified by the number of imaginary frequencies (NIMG) with NIMG=1, the vibrational modes, and “TS conformation” implemented in DMol3. The adsorption energy is defined by the formula of Eads =Esub +EX −E(X/sub), where E(X/sub) and Esub represent the total energies of the optimized equilibrium configurations for the substrate with and without adsorbates, respectively, and EX is the total energy of the corresponding isolated adsorbate in its ground state. With this definition, a higher Eads value means a stronger adsorption. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Models analysis Graphene with different nitrogen doping configurations were synthesized and proven with improved catalytic activity by experimental [62–64] and theoretical [31,32,65,66] studies, since the introduced nitrogen could tune the electronic redistribution and dramatically change the local reactivity [30]. The earlier experimental study pointed out that the pyridinic N was chiefly responsible for the high oxygen reduction reaction activity [29] among the three common N-doping species [26,67] (pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, and graphitic N). Liu et al. observed that the pyridinic N are the dominant structures when the nitrogen doped graphene annealed at ∼500K, and are more stable than the pyrrolic N [67]. Moreover, the formation energy of pyridinic N is calculated by Liu and coworkers [38]. They found that the formation energy goes down to the lowest (−9.27eV) when all the 3C atoms around the vacancy are replaced by N atoms to form a pyridinic N structure (marked as pyri-N3) due to the dangling bond number is minimum. The similar conclusions were drawn by Fujimoto and Saito [68] who investigated the formation, stabilities, and electronic properties of nitrogen defects in graphene using the DFT calculations. They addressed how the pyridinic N configurations are formed and revealed that the formation of pyridinic type defects were energetically more favorable than that of the substitutional N defects in presence of a vacancy in graphene [68]. Their further studies indicated also that the pyri-N3 exhibited higher reactivity for H2 dissociation than the graphitic N graphene [69,70]. More importantly, the pyri-N3 structure is quite active not only for adsorbing other molecules [71] but also for trapping the metal atoms [72], and the trapped metal atoms exhibited surprising catalytic activity for some reactions including CO oxidation [38,72]. Co and N codoped graphene were synthesized and proven with an outstanding activity for ORR both experimentally [49–51] and theoretically [46,48,53]. As presented below, Co and N codoped graphene with single metal Co incorporated with the pyri-N3 structure (Hereafter, marked as Co-N3-gra, see Fig. 1 a) owns exceptional stability and superior catalytic activity for CO oxidation. The most favorable adsorption structure of Co atom on the pyri-N3 is identified with the lowest total energy by considering all possible adsorption sites. We find that the single Co atom tends to be adsorbed at the vacancy site that is surrounded by three N atoms with the average NCo bond length of 1.83Å (Fig. 1a) which is smaller by about 0.26Å than PtN bond length [38], due to the smaller atomic radii of Co than Pt. Since the atomic radius of Co is larger than that of C, the Co atom is displaced outside from the support surface. The adsorption energy of Co on pyri-N3 substrate (4.84eV) is larger by about 0.37eV than that of Pt [38]. The large adsorption energy and the short CoN bond length indicate the tremendous interaction between Co and N atoms, which is supported by the pronounced charge density redistribution as presented in Fig. 1b. Yet the small amount of charge transfer (0.13 e) from Co to pyri-N3 support based on the Mulliken charge analysis [73] demonstrates the covalent feature between CoN. The mobility of Co on pyri-N3 substrate is studied to further examine the stability of the Co-N3-gra catalyst. We take the most stable adsorption structure as the IS, and the other possible stable adsorption sites (marked as ‘H’ and “B” in Fig. 1a) as FS. According to the TS calculations, the outward diffusion of Co from the most stable site to its adjacent hollow (H) and bridge (B) sites are endothermic by about 3.35 and 3.31eV with the diffusion barriers of 3.46 and 3.50eV, respectively, that are both higher than that of Pt [38]. These results indicate that the pyri-N3 substrate could efficiently stabilize the single Co atom and the outward diffusion of Co atom is hardly to take place both kinetically and thermodynamically, which are in accordance with the experimental observations that these bonded Co atoms by N atoms would not be removed easily during the chemical leaching process [49]. The electronic structures are analyzed to understand the interaction of Co with pyri-N3 support as well as the activity of Co-N3-gra catalyst. Comparing the total density of states (DOS) of pyri-N3 substrate with that of the Co-N3-gra system (Fig. 1c), we find that a valley in the DOS of pyri-N3 substrate at the Fermi energy vanished while a tall and broad peak appears at the corresponding energy site in the DOS of the Co-N3-gra system, arising mainly from the interaction of Co 3d states with N 2p states based on the PDOS analysis (Fig. 1d). The enhanced interaction of Co with N can be proven further by the strongly hybridization of N 2p states with the 3d and 3p states of Co. The depressed Co 3d peaks illustrate that charges transfer from Co to the pyri-N3 support, while the split Co 3d bands around the Fermi energy implies that an inverse charge contribution from pyri-N3 support to Co atom. The overlap of Co 3d with N 2p states around the Fermi level provides an evidence of covalent interaction between Co and pyri-N3 support, which is in agreement with the results mentioned above. The existence of slight overlap of Co 3d states with the total DOS of Co-N3-gra at the Fermi energy and the new peaks appeared around Fermi energy both prove that the Co-N3-gra may have superior activity toward CO oxidation. 3.2 The adsorption of reaction species Starting from the optimal structure of Co-N3-gra, various adsorption sites, including those near to and those far away from the central activated Co atom, are examined to find out the energetically most stable configurations of CO oxidation involved species (CO, O2, O, and CO2). The calculated results indicate that all reactants tend to be adsorbed at the Co site, implying that the Co dopants are the active sites of the Co-N3-gra catalyst, and the most stable adsorption configurations with the corresponding geometric parameters and adsorption energies for each of the adsorbates are depicted in Fig. 2 . CO tends to be adsorbed at the top site of Co atom with a side-on pattern by forming the OCo and CCo bonds of 2.01 and 1.94Å, respectively. The calculated adsorption energy is 1.21eV accompanied with electronic charge transfer of about 0.11 e from Co-N3-gra to CO. The transferred electrons occupy the 2π* states of CO and thus lead to the elongation of the CO bond to 1.21Å. The charge density difference map is depicted in the mid-column of Fig. 2a to make the charge redistribution visualized. We find that the charge accumulate mainly on the new formed CoC and CoO bonds, while the charge depletion regions are observed both on Co and CO, implying covalent interaction of CO with Co-N3-gra. In addition, the back-donation effect of CO can also be speculated from the results of charge depletion on CO and accumulation on Co and N atoms. The DOS analysis is done to understand the orbital interaction accompanied with the charge transfer, as shown in the right-column of Fig. 2a. The DOS depression of the Co 3d states at the Fermi energy is consistent with the facts of Co donating electrons to CO. Meanwhile, the back-donation of electrons from CO at Fermi energy resulting in the DOS peaks of Co broadened and split into two parts. After CO adsorption, the DOS of CO are all downward shifted and partially split due to the interaction with Co. The strong hybridization between the states of Co and those of CO below Fermi energy together with the slight overlap of the states above the Fermi energy indicates their strong interaction. For O2, a similar adsorption pattern with CO is found as shown in Fig. 2b. The O2 molecule lies on the top site of Co forming two OCo bonds of 1.84Å with an adsorption energy of 3.36eV. The big adsorption energy coupled with a large charge transfer from Co to O2 (0.51 e) enforce the bond length of O2 being elongated to 1.42Å. As known, the elongation of OO bond results commonly from the extra electrons entering into the 2π* states of O2 that subsequently lead to broadening and splitting of the 2π* states of O2 [18,20]. From the right panel of Fig. 2b, we find that a new low 2π* peak emerges at the 2eV blow the Fermi energy that strongly resonates with the d states of Co, while the main peak of the 2π* states has no obvious change at Fermi energy which implies that the OO bond may still be hard to break up, which is similar with the results of Wang et al. [46]. This will be discussed later. Upon O2 adsorption, the Co 3d states peak at the Fermi energy vanished but the peak at about 2eV below Fermi energy becomes corpulent due to the interaction of Co 3d states with the O2 2π* states. Meanwhile, the interaction of Co with O2 also leads to the depression of the DOS peaks of O2. The strong DOS resonance of Co with O2 could be observed both below and above Fermi energy, indicating a covalent nature of the interaction, which is accord with the charge density difference results of the charge accumulation on Co-O bonds (mid-panel of Fig. 2b). Both the Mulliken charge analysis and charge density difference indicate the electronic charge transfer from Co to adsorbed O2. Compared with O2, the atomic O is more strongly adsorbed on the Co-N3-gra, which is manifested by the bigger adsorption energy (5.97 vs 3.36eV) and the more shortened OCo bond (1.64 vs 1.84Å). There are about 0.48 electrons transferred to the adsorbed O atom from the Co-N3-gra support and the charge density difference further proves that those charges are mainly from the Co dopants (mid-panel of Fig. 2c). Comparing the DOS curve of the O adsorbed on Co-N3-gra with that of O2, we find that the redistribution of electronic states of O is quite different with that of O2, indicating that O2 is not fully activated and the scission of OO bond might be difficult by Co-N3-gra only. This is in agreement with the results of previous DOS analysis about O2 adsorbed on Co-N3-gra, and further manifested by the following kinetic calculations. In addition, we find that the structural distortion of the Co-N3-gra catalyst induced by O adsorption is insignificant (∼0.04Å), and the similar phenomenon is also observed for O2 and CO adsorption, which confirms that the Co-N3-gra catalyst is stable for catalyzing CO oxidation. The CO2 is weakly adsorbed on Co-N3-gra, which is characterized with smaller adsorption energy (0.83eV), larger distance of CO2 molecule with Co-N3-gra support (2.10Å), and negligible charge transfer (0.09 e) from CO2 to the catalyst. The weak adsorption of CO2 on Co-N3-gra is further proved by analyzing the DOS and the charge density redistribution (Fig. 2d). The insignificant charge accumulation regions appeared at the Co-O bond indicates that the Co-N3-gra support could not bind CO2 stably. The almost invisible electronic states hybridization of Co with CO2 reflects their weak interaction, which is favorable for CO2 desorption. 3.3 Mechanisms of CO oxidation Two types of CO oxidation mechanisms, namely the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) and the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanisms, are widely recognized [13,18,38]. The E-R mechanism is featured with the CO molecules directly react with the already activated O2 to produce and subsequently dissociate the CO3 intermediate. The L-H mechanism starts with the coadsorption of CO and O2 molecules before reaction and followed by formation and dissociation of the OOCO intermediate. Both mechanisms are comparatively studied here to identify the optimal reaction path. As mentioned above, the O2 will preferentially occupy the activated Co sites since the adsorption of O2 on Co-N3-gra is stronger than that of CO. So we start our investigation with the E-R mechanism. The optimized structure of each state along the MEP is displayed in Fig. 3 . The configuration of a CO suspended above the O2 preoccupied Co-N3-gra is taken as the initial state (IS). The reaction of CO with the preadsorbed O2 over Co-N3-gra through the E-R mechanism requires the suspended CO moving forward to the adsorbed O2. As the CO approaching to O2, the CO bond of CO and the OO bond of O2 are elongated simultaneously, and finally reach the transition state (TS1). Passing over TS1, an intermediate state (MS) of CO3 located on the Co atom is produced by inserting CO completely into the OO bond and the corresponding energy barrier (Ebar1) is calculated to be 1.26eV accompanied with about 4.29eV energy released. The big energy barrier of CO3 formation is due to breaking the strong OO bond, which is accordance with previous DOS analysis. Moreover, we find that the dissociation of CO3 to produce the final product CO2 and an adsorbed O (FS) is thermodynamically hardly to happen since the MS is more stable by about 1.37eV than the FS. Similar results have been observed for CO oxidation over other catalysts including Pt/N3 catalyst [21,22,38]. The quite big barriers of CO3 formation and dissociation indicate that the CO oxidation on Co-N3-gra via the E-R mechanism is difficult. We therefore focus our attention on the L-H mechanism in the following sections. The most stable coadsorption structure of CO and O2 is firstly revealed since it is prerequisite step for the L-H mechanism. We find that the coadsorption of CO and O2 on Co-N3-gra is by 1.20eV more stable than that of a CO suspended above the preadsorbed O2 on Co-N3-gra. The calculated coadsorption energy of CO and O2 on Co-N3-gra is 4.69eV, which is slightly larger than the sum of their respective adsorption energies (4.58eV), indicating that the cooperative adsorption of CO and O2 is favorable and the suspended CO will proactively migrate to the activated Co atom to form the coadsorption configurations. To manifest this speculation, the configuration of a CO resided at about 5.00Å above the Co-N3-gra basal surface with an O2 preadsorbed at the activated Co atom is further to be optimized, and it is found that the CO moves gradually closer to the Co-N3-gra and finally locates at the Co top site. These results indicate that the activated Co atom is available for the coadsorption of CO and O2, and the migration of CO from the vacuum to Co atom is barrierless. More importantly, the intensive coadsorption of CO and O2 has caused only a tiny deformation (∼0.08Å), which proves the Co-N3-gra catalyst is stable in the reaction condition again. The atomic structures of various states along the MEP of the L-H mechanism and the corresponding structure parameters are displayed in Fig. 4 . In the IS, the CO and OO bonds are activated to 1.15 and 1.40Å, respectively. To react, the O2 molecule turns around with one of oxygen atom breaking away from the Co atom and approaching the carbon atom of CO to generate a new CO bond as shown in TS1. Then a peroxide-like intermediate (MS) is formed with an activation barrier of 0.86eV and endothermic by 0.34eV. The reaction continuously proceeds from MS to FS through an almost barrierless pathway (∼0.01eV), where the OO and CoC bonds are broken and a CO2 molecule is formed, leaving an atomic O adsorbed on the Co atom. Once formed, the CO2 molecule will desorb easily with an atomic O remaining on the Co atom, which can be used to oxidize the subsequent coming CO molecule. A configuration of CO staying 3.50Å away from the preadsorbed O atom is selected as the IS (Fig. 5 ) to investigate the reaction of a gaseous CO molecule with the adsorbed O atom. The structural parameters and the corresponding energy barrier during the reaction process are depicted in Fig. 5. In the oxidization process, the C atom of CO approaches the adsorbed O, developing a new CO bond and attracting the adsorbed O away from the Co atom as shown in TS. Then the adsorbed O is taken further away from Co atom by CO and finally forming a CO2. This reaction is exothermic by 1.09eV with an activation barrier of 0.47eV. The large exothermicity is also helpful for desorption of CO2 and regeneration of the activated sites for subsequent CO oxidation. In summary, the relatively large reaction barriers of CO3 formation and decomposition indicate that the CO oxidation through the E-R mechanism as a starting point is not preferable. While the low barrier to produce OOCO from the reaction of coadsorbed CO and O2 implies that the reaction may be initiated through L-H mechanism and followed by the E-R reaction of CO+O→CO2. The relatively larger adsorption energy of O2 on Co-N3-gra than that of CO implies that the CO oxidation along the tri-molecular Eley-Rideal mechanism proposed by Mao et al. [74] is irrespective. Table 1 summarizes the rate-limiting steps and the corresponding activation barriers of CO oxidation on other similar catalysts. Comparably, the catalytic performance of noble-metal-free Co-N3-gra catalyst for CO oxidation is higher than that of commonly used noble metal catalysts such as Pt [1,13,75–77], Au [78] and is also comparable to the other metal-graphene [21,22] or metal-NB catalyst [74,79]. The reactivity of Co-N3-gra is found to be slightly lower than the Al-Gra [80], while the Al-Gra is less stable than Co-N3-gra during the CO adsorption process according to the results of Ao et al. [81]. Meanwhile, Ao and coworkers pointed out that the performance of Al-Gra for CO oxidation is tightly limited by the narrow operating temperatures. Additionally, although the theoretical studies on the Al-Gra are abundant [82–84], to the best of our knowledge, the relevant experiment works about the synthesis of Al-Gra are absent to date. Our current results indicate that the non-noble-metal Co-N3-gra catalyst is highly efficient for CO oxidation. 4 Conclusions An efficient non-noble-metal catalyst of a single cobalt atom incorporated with pyridinic nitrogen graphene (Co-N3-gra) is proposed. The first-principles calculations are performed to investigate the geometric and electronic structures of the proposed Co-N3-gra. We find that the single Co atom can be stably embedded into the pyridinic N vacancy sites, and the resulting Co-N3-gra complex exhibits attractive activity towards the CO oxidation. The kinetics results indicate that the L-H mechanism is more preferable than the E-R mechanism for the CO oxidation reaction. The formation of the intermediate product OOCO with an activation barrier of 0.86eV is identified as the rate-determining step of CO oxidation along the L-H mechanism. Our results also illustrate that the E-R mechanism is hardly to happen due to the quite large barriers of CO3 formation (1.26eV) and dissociation (1.79eV). Summarily, Co-N3-gra can be used as a low cost and efficient catalyst for CO oxidation, and the current results will be helpful for designing novel single non-noble-metal-based catalysts with lower cost and higher activity. coredata.dc:description: The low operating temperature, high efficiency and noble-metal-free are the goal of the ideal catalysts. In present study, an efficient noble-metal-free catalyst for CO oxidation with a single cobalt atom incorporated with pyridinic nitrogen graphene (Co-N3-gra) is proposed. The catalytic activity for CO oxidation via various mechanisms on the Co-N3-gra catalyst is investigated using the first-principles method. It is found that the CO oxidation occurs preferably following the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism (CO+O2 →OOCO→CO2 +O) with an energy barrier of 0.86eV for the rate-limiting step of OOCO formation. Our findings prove that the activity of noble-metal-free Co-N3-gra catalyst is comparable to or even higher than some other single noble-metal-graphene based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Single non-noble-metal cobalt atom stabilized by pyridinic vacancy graphene: An efficient catalyst for CO oxidation
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
